Dear Mark,

Thank you for reaching out. I’m happy to share some broad, non-client-specific pointers that have served us well when preparing and filing motions in state court.  The suggestions below are high-level and should be adapted to the nuances of your jurisdiction and the particular judge’s standing orders.

1. Confirm the governing rules early.
   • Cross-check the latest edition of the state rules of civil procedure, any local county rules, and the judge’s individual practices.  Pay special attention to page limits, font/spacing requirements, and timing rules for filing and service.

2. Build a concise but complete record.
   • Identify the key documents that must accompany the motion (affidavits, exhibits, transcripts, etc.).  Make sure each exhibit is clearly tabbed and cited in the brief so the court can locate it quickly.
   • Where feasible, include a short practitioner’s affidavit that lays out the procedural history in numbered paragraphs—that often saves the court time and avoids confusion.

3. Focus the brief on the dispositive issue.
   • Lead with the controlling rule or standard of review, then show—fact by fact—how it is met.  Judges routinely comment that the most persuasive motions are the ones that can be “scanned” and digested in minutes.
   • Use headings that state the desired finding (e.g., “The Contract Is Enforceable Because the Statute of Frauds Is Satisfied”).  It guides the reader and becomes a roadmap for the eventual order.

4. Draft a proposed order.
   • Even if not strictly required, attaching a proposed order that tracks the requested relief (with blank signature/date lines) demonstrates professionalism and can accelerate a ruling.

5. Provide notice and confer.
   • Many judges require or appreciate a 3-to-5-day advance notice email or phone call to opposing counsel.  Even where not mandated, a short “meet-and-confer” can pre-empt objections to format or scheduling.

6. Mind the filing logistics.
   • Confirm whether your court accepts e-filing, paper filing, or both.  If hard copies are needed, prepare the correct number of bound sets plus any courtesy copies for chambers.
   • When filing electronically, combine documents into as few PDFs as the system allows—courts often restrict the number of separate uploads.

7. Calendar follow-ups.
   • Note the hearing date (if one is automatically assigned) or, if the court sets hearings separately, diary a reminder to request oral argument within the prescribed window.
   • Track the deadline for any reply brief; many jurisdictions give 5–10 days.

8. Keep exhibits confidential when necessary.
   • If you anticipate sealing issues, file the motion in two parts: a public version with redactions and a sealed version containing the full exhibits, accompanied by a short motion to seal.

If you’d like a checklist to run through before filing, feel free to let me know and I can send you a generic template we keep internally.

I hope this helps, and please don’t hesitate to reach out if anything needs clarification.

Best regards,

Jane Doe
Carter & Goldstein LLP
(555) 555-1234 | jdoe@cartergoldstein.com
